issues.title: Working with python3
issues.body:
I want to use this judge in my programming class which use `python3` as a main language. So I tried to modify the `compile` and `run` script to use `/usr/bin/python3` but it failed. `a.out` run smoothly (via terminal) but it didn't produce any output to `output.txt`. Here are some modification I'd tried out:
- I've changed `/usr/bin/python` to `/usr/bin/python3` in both `compile` and `run` scripts
- As in python3, `.pyc` file is created in `__pycache__` folder so I add some `cp` command in `compile` script to copy it to same level as `a.out` with a new name `<source>.pyc` (instead of `<source>.cpython-xx.pyc`).

So I want some advices or suggestions from dev team on how should I do to make cafe grader supports `python3`. Thanks in advance!

issue_comments.body: In addition, when I checked `result` file in each `judge/result/{user}/{prob_name}/{submission_id}/test_results/{test_no}` folder, it was written `Forbidden access to file 'dev/urandom'` and `output.txt` is empty. Also a judgement of all cases is marked as `x`.

issues.title: box64.cc doesn't work in Ubuntu 14.04.1
issues.body:
box64.cc gives error during run with the `-a 2 -f -T -t <time> -m <mem> -i <input> -o output.txt` arguments

The error is:

```
read(mem): Input/output error
wait4: unknown status
```

Please note that the box script works well with Ubuntu 12.04.4 but fails with 14.04.1.

The solution is to update the rails version in Gemfile to 3.2.19 and recompile the assets.
See [this pull request](https://github.com/jittat/cafe-grader-web/pull/4) for more information.

issue_comments.body:
I don't know where I miss it but I cannot get the 2.1.2 to work perfectly on 14.04 LTS.

With 2.1.2, the in_place_editing is not working on my machine and it is not possible to toggle the problem. It reports `Template is missing`. I re-tested on a new virtual machine running a fresh install of 14.04 LTS and also on another machine running openSUSE 13.1 and the result is still the same.

In fact, even with 1.9.2 it won't work unless I call `rake assets:precompile`. For 1.9.2, this is not a big if we deployed via passenger because we have to call `rake assets:precompile`

With 2.1.2, however, I cannot get it to working even after calling `rake assets:precompile`. Passenger won't work as well.

Strange enough, if I install 1.9.2 together with 2.1.2, and switch to 1.9.2 before calling `rake assets:precompile` and then switch back to 2.1.2, it is working again. 

Step to reproduce:
1. get the latest installation script (one that use 2.1.2)
2. run the installation script.
3. create a  new problem (or import a new problem)
4. try to toggle the problem 

Sadly, I don't know how to fix it. I prefer 2.1.2 over 1.9.2.

I took the updated version of box from MOE by Martin Mares and made it compilable separately from MOE. I also changed the output format to be compatible with the old box64.cc . You could try it from https://github.com/nattee/cafe-grader-judge-scripts/blob/algo-bm/std-script/box64-new.c 

However, I also modified it to display memory in KiB which is not the same as the original. You might need to revert it back or update your std-script accordingly. 

This version works with Ubuntu 14.04.1 and also with openSUSE 13.1. Use gcc --std=c99 -o box box64-new.c to compile.

issue_comments.body: I think option (1) can be very dangerous.  Imagine you accidentally delete a problem.  For now, I think I'll pull in your commit as a quick fix.
Sorry for a fairly late reply.  I think that the problem is with the sandbox.  It prevents the python interpreter from accessing some system files.  I'll look into that to find some fix.
